DataElement.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Health Comorbidity Complication Factor Six Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Records the patient's pre-existing medical conditions, factors influencing health status, and/or complications during the patient's hospital stay for the treatment of this cancer using ICD-9-CM codes.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Health Comorbidity Complication Factor Six
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The patient's pre-existing medical conditions, factors influencing health status, and/or complications during the patient's hospital stay for the treatment of this cancer using ICD-9-CM codes.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Property.preferredDefinition: The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.:The coexistence of two or more disease processes.:Complication; any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of (or because of) another disease.:No Value Exists:Factor; anything that contributes causally to a result.

Concepts.definition: Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.
The coexistence of two or more disease processes.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.
A natural number greater than 5 and less than 7 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of five and one.
Anything that contributes causally to a result.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Removed special characters for MDR data migration. 3.9.20 mc

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: ICD-9-CM codes used for recording the patient's pr-existing medical conditions, factors influencing health status, and/or complications during the hospital stay for the treatment of cancer.  All are considered secondary diagnoses. [Explanatory Comment: Refer to FORDS for additional instructions.  If no secondary diagnoses are documented, enter Comorbid/Complication 1 as 00000 meaning 'No secondary diagnosis documented.'  Leave subsequent Comorbid/Complication 2 to 10 blank.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.:Factor; anything that contributes causally to a result.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.
Anything that contributes causally to a result.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ValueDomain.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ReferenceDocuments.description: For additional details see NAACCR, Standards for Cancer Registries Volume II, Version 11.1 Data Standards and Data Dictionary (5/4/06)

ReferenceDocuments.name: FORDS Manual, Revised 2009
ReferenceDocuments.description: See FORDS Manual for specifications of codes and data entry rules.

ReferenceDocuments.name: (ICD-9-CM) International Classification of Diseases,Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification
ReferenceDocuments.description: The International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) is based on the World Health Organization's Ninth Revision, International Classification of Diseases (ICD-9). ICD-9-CM is the official system of assigning codes to diagnoses and procedures associated with hospital utilization in the United States. The ICD-9 is used to code and classify mortality data from death certificates.

ReferenceDocuments.name: ICD-9-CM Valid Values
ReferenceDocuments.description: The following ICD-9-CM Codes may be used: Codes 00100-13980, 24000-99990, E8700-E8799, E9300-E9499, V0720-V0739, V1000-V1590, V2220- V2310, V2540, V4400-V4589, and V5041-V5049. If no secondary diagnoses are documented, enter Comorbid/Complication 1 as 00000 meaning 'No secondary diagnosis documented.' Leave subsequent Comorbid/Complication 2 to 10 blank. Refer to FORDS for additional instructions.
